risk_analysis.site: Remains of a Roman-era residential district
risk_analysis.risk_name: Radiations that leads to thermal inhomogeneities
risk_analysis.scale_a_description: More intense peaks in the summers of 2021 and 2022 due to warmer temperatures together with emergency operations by the LMCU degree course in Conservation and Restoration of Cultural Heritage at Unibo contributed to the rise of the two peaks. One year after the biocidal treatment, biological colonisation reappeared, and in untreated areas during the summer months it grew exponentially due to high relative humidity, prolonged sun exposure and a constant temperature of 21-23 degrees. Cumulative process; in this case, the level of damage relevant to the context is selected and the time needed to accumulate this damage is assessed. Time needed to accumulate the damage: the amount of Lux/year itself complies with the regulations regarding the lighting of stone materials (in the most extreme cases it does not exceed 90 average annual lux) but there is collateral damage: one year after the biocidal treatment, it takes 5 months for the indirect phenomenon of biological colonisation to reappear.
risk_analysis.scale_b_description: For cumulative risks, the extent of the damage (4) and the point in time (5 years) selected in point A are assessed. Type of material moderately susceptible: natural and artificial stone materials. Loss of value for each object: growth of biological patina mainly on portions with bedding mortar only and production of stains. The main element affected is the geometric mosaic with floral motifs (6) exposed to sunlight from the glass trapdoor and in other portions of opus sectile (numbered 7,8,10). Estimated fraction of loss for each object: about 0.6-2% on average. Small loss of value for each affected object.
risk_analysis.scale_c_description: Number of pavements affected by biological colonisation due to artificial and natural lighting = 4/12 Number of most susceptible pavements among those affected = 2/4 Number of high-value pavements among the susceptible ones = 1/2 1/12 x 100 = 8.3% loss of the most susceptible high-value pavements A significant loss of the total value of the collection
risk_analysis.risk_description: The lighting system and the unscreened natural light coming from the glass ceiling will cause thermal inhomogeneities on the surfaces, favouring biological colonisation.

risk_analysis.site: Remains of a Roman-era residential district
risk_analysis.risk_name: Development of efflorescence
risk_analysis.scale_a_description: Cumulative process; in this case, the level of damage relevant to the context is selected and the time needed to accumulate this damage is assessed. Time needed to accumulate the damage: every winter, so approximately every 6-8 months, the phenomenon of salt crystallisation occurs, starting around November and ending in March (about 5 months).
risk_analysis.scale_b_description: For cumulative risks, the extent of the damage (5) and the point in time (5 years) selected in point A are assessed. Type of material moderately susceptible: natural and artificial stone materials. Loss of value for each object: efflorescence, lifting of flakes of stone material (as with slates) which in certain situations leads to the detachment of portions of flakes from the stone crusts of the opus sectile, production of whitish patina. The main elements affected are the geometric mosaic with floral motifs and the portion in medieval cocciopesto (area 6), areas 4, 7, 8, and 10 in opus sectile, area 2 in opus signinum. Estimated fraction of loss for each object: 2-6% Almost total loss of value for each affected object.
risk_analysis.scale_c_description: Number of pavements affected by salt crystallisation = 10/12 Number of most susceptible pavements among those affected = 7/10 Number of high-value pavements among the susceptible ones = 4/7 4/12 x 100 = 33.3% loss of high-value pavements (areas 2, 7, 8, 10) 2/12 x 100 = 8.3% loss of medium-value pavements (areas 4 and 6) 1/12 x 100 = 8.3% loss of low-value pavement (3) A significant loss of the total value of the collection
risk_analysis.risk_description: During the winter periods, salt crystallisation will occur due to a decrease in internal relative humidity,

risk_analysis.risk_description: An earthquake of moderate magnitude (Richter scale 5.0-5.9) will fracture the floors of the archaeological site and the building's structures, making the basement unusable.

risk_analysis.site: Remains of a Roman-era residential district
risk_analysis.risk_name: Moderate earthquake case 2
risk_analysis.risk_description: The buildings built up to 2003 without seismic regulations near the Chamber of Commerce (that could be untouched) will collapse following an earthquake of medium magnitude (Richter scale 5.0-5.9). During an earthquake there will be many displaced people in the neighborhood where the archaeological site is located and the operations to secure the archaeological site will be neglected in order to provide priority assistance to civilians.

risk_analysis.site: Remains of a Roman-era residential district

A strong earthquake strong or very strong magnitude will break the suction pump mechanism and the archaeological site will flood.
